Award.AwardTitle: Preparing American Indian Students for STEM Careers On and Beyond the Reservation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this project is to increase the quantity and quality of American Indian students pursuing careers in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics by: 1) Developing and sustaining new STEM degree programs; 2) improving STEM instructional and research methods; and 3) building student capacity. The methods for accomplishing this objective will include: 1) Expanding curriculum, strengthening the Natural Science degree program, and developing an Associate in Science degree program in Natural Resources; 2) providing professional development opportunities for STEM faculty through workshops, conferences, and classes; and 3) increasing opportunities for student research, internships, workforce placement, and increased global awareness.

Leaach Lake Tribal College will develop capacity to transform the way math and science is viewed on the reservation by promoting the integration of hands-on research activities and culturally infused STEM education that will greatly contribute to increasing the number of STEM graduates needed to meet local and national workforce demands.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In 2013 the STEM efforts by the LLTC resulted in the development and accreditation by the HLC of the Associate in Science Degree in Earth System Science that will not only prepare students for transfer into four-year degree programs, but is designed to give them a competitive edge in the local job market through its provision of a strong base of traditional ecology knowledge and insight into managing forests on tribal lands. In 2014 LLTC developed and achieved an accreditation by the HLC for the Associate in Science Degree in Forest Ecology. This degree was designed to engage students with hands-on learning in the forested lands of northern Minnesota and the natural assets found upon the Leech Lake Reservation. In addition, the grant allowed for the purchase of equipment necessary to prepare students for field work in the Forest Resources field, field trips, internships and research collaborations. 

 

LLTC continued to support and build STEM partnerships during this grant period through their continued research on Climate Change with the USDA Forest Services and the development of a partnership with the Leech Lake Band of Ojibwe Department of Resource Management (LLDRM) to develop a Forest Management Curriculum for the Bugonaygeshig School in Bena in efforts to inspire students into STEM careers. LLTC was successful in the publication of 1,000 copies of our Indigenous (Nindinawemaaganidog) plant book and the development of a digital version Webpage.  This research publication includes a wide variety of plant related information such as biological and ecological physiology/function, as well as, providing indigenous knowledge necessary to understand the importance of plant species in Northern MN. This book sets the stage for future interdisciplinary education efforts and collaborations.

 

The Internship Program consistently grew during this award cycle and resulted in 41 Native Students successfully completing summer internships during that period, which is a noticeable increase from the 36 documented within the prior grant period. In addition to their involvement with local, state and federal agencies in STEM-related fields, LLTC students have engaged in internships in the following remote locations:

2016- Salish Koteni College Internship conducting water quality testing 2017- NASA Internship through Haskell University conducting climate change research with a faculty member at Haskell.

2017- US Forestry Research Station at Itasca Community College studying the changing forest and what methods would work best to increase evergreens in new areas.

In addition to the creation and maintenance of an Environmental Awareness Website (Gidakiim.com) which includes global, national, regional and local examples of major environmental issues, an outdoor Lab was created in an area on campus which was planted in native grasses and fruiting shrubs.

Academic enhancements this grant period included the development of the Basic Computer Applications I (ITECH 100) course and integration of the use of the 3D printer successfully into curriculum, a hybrid General Biology I course, the redesign of Woodland Plants (FOR 110) based on faculties professional experience working with agency forest ecologists, the redesign of Wildlife Biology (BIO 130) and Survey and Measurement (FOR 240) prompted by input from DNR hiring managers and their identification of the need for a greater emphasis on “forest inventory techniques” by potential hires, and revived Computer Programming (ITECH 210) and Web Page Design (ITECH 270) classes.

Additional achievements during this grant period regarding building a successful tutoring program include in increase in available on-line math courses, math tutor and instructor assistance in MAT 093 and MAT 140, and the Utilization of Pearson MyMathLab and Advanced Algebra Courses. The LLTC Math tutoring program provided individual, one-on-one tutoring for 103 of 244 (42%) math students over a three year period resulting in higher rates of student success. The number of upper level students receiving math tutoring has increased, and instructors are using MYMATHLAB for online tutoring.

Alliances with North Star STEM alliance, Indigenous Peoples Climate Change Work Group, and Chippewa National Forest Climate Charter Group were strengthened over this grant period, a redesign of existing science lab was conducted to assure functionality, the Pond Watch research project (Biological assessment of pools in relation to climate change and disturbances) was completed and disseminated, and continued collaborations with AISES chapters in 3 local high schools occurred in conjunction with on-going support of the STEM college corner in each school to increase exposure to and ignite interest in STEM careers.

During the grant period our institution experience great growth in our course offerings, research outcomes and internship opportunities. We currently have 31 students still enrolled within their degreed STEM program and have identified (and are addressing within this proposal) significant barriers that impact our students and the outcomes of their educational experience.
